unnormalised: So, you're worried about your ticker? Join the club! Cardiology, the study of the heart, is no laughing matter... except when it is! Let's face it, if we don't poke a little fun at this vital organ, we'll all end up with stress-induced tachycardia, which Dr. Sharma down the road (Apollo Hospitals) says is *definitely* not good. First things first, remember that your heart is like a Bollywood hero – dramatic, prone to exaggerated reactions, and occasionally in need of rescuing.

unnormalised: Speaking of heroes, remember that time your uncle ate 10 samosas at Diwali? That, my friends, is a classic case of "acute myocardial infarction waiting to happen." Suddenly feeling chest pain after stuffing your face with mithai? Don't Google it! Just call an ambulance and tell them you suspect a possible blockage. They might scoff, but hey, better safe than sorry. The ambulance guys will probably ask for your ECG report. Don't be like my neighbor, Rajesh, who thought ECG stood for "Extra Crispy Goodness." He tried to order one from KFC.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole world of medications. Ask your doctor about statins if you're above 40 yrs of age. It can lower your cholesterol. Brand names that are popular are Atorvastatin 10mg and Rosuvastatin 5mg. Some people prefer natural methods to lower their bad cholesterols, but those usually don't have the same effect.

unnormalised: And let's not forget the lingo! Angioplasty sounds like a fancy gardening term, but it's actually a procedure to unclog those pesky arteries. Cardiomyopathy? Sounds like a really intense yoga pose. And atrial fibrillation? Sounds like a debate tournament for tiny heart chambers. Don't even get me started on CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting). They take a vein from your leg and use it to bypass a blocked artery in your heart. In other words, your leg is donating to your heart fund! How’s that for generosity?

unnormalised: Now, I am no Dr., but I do know that your heart needs love. Cut down on the oily biryani, start walking 30 minutes a day (or at least chase the auto-rickshaw driver for a fair price), and maybe, just maybe, your heart will forgive you for all those late-night chai sessions. If you're a heavy smoker, it is highly advisable to quit. Maybe attend some workshops where they counsel you.
